A01.title: Public transport fleet supply
A01.description: The supply of public buses indicates the capacity of public transport given the population. If other public transport modes are available (e.g. metro), these could be converted into bus equivalents.

A02.title: Public transport accessibility
A02.description: The level of service and coverage of public transport networks. The policy goal in Jaipur is to supply 60% of people and 50% of jobs with high-frequency services within 500m.
A02.target: 50% of population within 500m of public transit

A03.title: Pedestrian friendly streets
A03.description: The provision of walking facilities at a minimum level of quality. This includes footpaths, crossings, signalling at junctions and access to PT stops. This indicator should be expanded to consider step-free access and inclusive design.
A03.target: 85% of major roads equipped with continuous footpaths

A04.title: Cycling infrastructure coverage
A04.description: The provision of cycling facilities at a minimum level of quality, including cycling lanes and storage.

A05.title: Drainage system coverage
A05.description: The provision of sufficient drainage to avoid disruptions that primarily affect non-motorised modes and thus encourage acquisition of a private vehicle.
A05.target: 90% coverage of arterial roads with modern drainage

A06.title: Trained motor vehicle drivers
A06.description: Driver training is important for safe driving, which includes being considerate to non-motorised transport users.
A06.target: 100% of drivers certified in safety protocols

A07.title: Transport budget
A07.description: Expenditure on transport indicates to which extent an efficient transport system can be developed and maintained.

A08.title: Local traffic flows
A08.description: Enforcement of traffic rules and regulations will ensure less traffic disorders at locations with high density of activities. Data about traffic flow can be collected more easily using sensors and cameras.

A09.title: Organised road use
A09.description: This is the share of encroached footpaths by vendings stall, parking, debris or shop extension. Obstructions cause local traffic disorder on both footpaths and carraigeways.

A10.title: Parking management
A10.description: Managed parking spcaes. Parking rules enforcement is important to avoid local traffic disorder and protect and promote uninhibted non-motorised road use.
A10.target: 100 car-equivalent managed parking spaces with fee collection

B01.title: Reduction of private vehicles
B01.description: The vehicle (two and four wheelers) registrations rate indicates the level of private motorisation.

B02.title: Reduction of motorised traffic
B02.description: Traffic volumes relative to capacity at critical points in the network. A reduction in motor vehicle traffic reduces the risk of congestion across the network.
B02.target: A ratio of 1.1 in peak hours.

B03.title: Decline in accidents
B03.description: Accident rates result from the degree to which the transport system is well managed and regulations are enforced. Accidents should be broken down by socio-demographic groups.

B04.title: Walking and cycling share
B04.description: Uptake of walking and cycling is a desirable mobility outcome.
B04.target: 35% of all trips involve walking and/or cycling

B05.title: Public transport ridership
B05.description: Public transport ridership suports the efficiency and environmental sustainability of travel. It is heavily affected by the level of services afforded by the transport system.
B05.target: 50% of all trips made by public transport

B06.title: Intermediate public transport
B06.description: Trips made by Intermediate Public Transport (IPT, e.g. auto rickshaws) relative to trips made by public tranpsort (PT). IPT should fill service gaps and offer last-mile mobility. Ideally, IPT is used for access and egress of public transport users.
B06.target: 2 trips made by intermediate public transport per PT trip
